content.description:
Great jughaul until the break, then a tweaky tech-face section below the anchors. Great fun.

It's almost impossible to direct people on this wall of bolts. It's the Boltline directly right of Naysayer, which is the bolt line directly right of Building a Mystery.  Both Naysayer and Alternative Medicine climb past a large, notable shelf ~2/3 of the way up, but Alternative Medicine tackles the bulging arete below it. Also, the stations are different, Alternative Medicine climbs to two chain anchors of equal length, where Naysayer does not. You'll figure it out. Probably. Good luck.
6 bolts, anchors.

Easiest route that leads to the top of Doctor's Wall. Consistent 5.10 climbing with some nice moves and rests, no surprise. 
 A single 70m is enough to rappel to the ground (over the boulders).

Rightmost route that gets to the top of Doctor's Wall. It can be approached from either side but scrambling on the right is easier (i.e. go around the boulders). The route starts right of the end of the ledge.
8 bolts to a chain anchor with a very nice ledge.

Great route full of technical climbing and interesting movement right until the chains.

Start with the fixed draw traverse and go straight up from the second fixed draw.
6 bolts.

Climb three bolts of blocky climbing until moving right to a line of bolts moving towards a small overlap. Extend bolt 3 and enjoy some beautiful edges until you reach the cruxy overlap. The crux climbs like granite. Gastons and side pulls will get you to the good holds above.

First route on the left side of the wall. An 11a branches off left at bolt 3. 
All bolted.

Starts the same as Reckless Negligence (hard start eases up before a tree stump), then up a tricky crack on the right before hitting the main crack. It's possible to avoid the tricky crack by stepping left at the stump but it' not any easier, and the gear is worse. Climbing improves as it gets steeper higher.

Begin at the far left end of the face and take a direct line up left of Naturopath
Mixed - 1 bolts and a wide range of gear. Rap hangers well above the ledge up top.

An outstanding route. Go straight up from the second to last fixed draw. Well spaced buckets, except at the mid-height crux. Leads up to a flake crack on a vertical wall.

Second from the left on the fixed traverse.
10 bolts.

The extension of Nurse Minitweak adds a boulder problem at the top.  Try to unweight the forearms for a bit at the chains and then power through to the roof.  Surviving the mid-crux clip is the key to success.  



Obvious extension of Nurse Minitweak

Bolts

climbs.name: Dr. Suess' Wild Ride
climbs.fa: Pete Lindgren '09, Prep. by Cody Leyden

content.description:
Start up the right side of a giant flake/off-width or chimney up and skip the first 2 bolts. Smash your way through easy climbing to a good rest below a mid-height boulder (thin, slightly overhanging). Surmount the boulder to another good rest and collect yourself for the real climb which is typical of Doctor's Wall style- a burly boulder nearly at the chains.  

A beta note- there are at least 2 strategies to pull the bulge at the top; underclings trending right, or a more recently discovered crimp sequence going straight up/slightly left. The new sequence may result in a lower difficulty rating...eventually. 



Look for "Piled Higher and Steeper", the off-width that splits Doctor's Wall. The Dr. Suess bolt line is immediately right of the crack. 

13 bolts, chains with biners

A slightly tricky start requires stepping over a deep whole - blowing the first bolt would be bad. Follow left facing flakes up to a reachy crux. Continue up large flakes to a small roof. Smooth rock at the top. Really fun!

Right of Hypocritical Alternative Billing - you need to scramble up some boulders to get to the start.
11 bolts.

Continues from the chains of Grin And Bear It. Follow the obvious crack out right and keep it together as you attempt to clear the bulge.

Choose the rightmost set of bolts after reaching the anchors of Grin And Bear It.
11 bolts and chains.

Traverse your way in from Suess, connecting the turbo jugs and bolts aiming for the black streak and the chain draw at the roof. Skip/long-draw several bolts on the way. 

A mini-boulder leads to a massive rest, which is immediately followed by a more substantial boulder using an undercling and small edges, which takes you to a rest where you can clip the chain draw. From here it's just a boulder problem and 4 bolts of super pumpy climbing - compression, big moves, techy footwork. It is on you, and supremely good!



Start in the prominent crack that splits Doctors' wall, clip bolts, going right when the climbing seems reasonable to get to the bolt line in the black streak. Note, GQ shares a few bolts with Tale of Two Guys, which branches to the left of the black streak. 

You can cool guy direct start by stick clipping the chain at the bottom, bouldering to a rest and then climbing GQ. 

13 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

Follow the thin-looking seam up through some bouldery bulges. Eventually trends leftwards to a set of anchors nestled under the overhanging dihedral. The extension directly above is Grin Reaper 12d, and the one that traverses out right along the crack is The Future is Now 11d.

Look for the thin seam to the left of the detached block that Salvation starts on.
5 bolts and chains.

After climbing Alternative Medecine, clip the chains and keep on climbing into the awesome undercling crack feature. Aesthetic climbing on incut crack is followed by narrowing crack until you reach the bolted belay station.



Extesion to Alternative Medecine. Obvious flayky crack system on the right of the wall.

7 bolts

A fun romp up the right side of the Megawall, this is one of the warm-ups for the area. Follows the obvious features up the wall. Short people will be annoyed by the high bolt off the ledge high on the route, but the moves off the ledge are fairly secure.

Immediately right of the Naysayer.
6 bolts.

A mellow start on an arete becomes increasingly more bouldery on the way to the first small roof. Two inobvious crimps above permit access to a thin face where the essential holds form a path through the lichen. Follow a delicate but pleasant crack up to an odd, small roof, and use judicious footwork to cruise to the chains. Unexpectedly high quality to popularity ratio.

Begins on the arete at the far left end of Doctor's wall, trending leftwards onto a thin-looking face and up a crack. Ends just after the odd, small roof visible from the ground at the top of the crack.
15 bolts and chains. A long draw (60 cm) on the bolt below the first bulge is nice.

First pitch only*. Follow the corner up to the roof, making use of good stems, before being forced out left. A good rest hold can be found here. Next, make a balancy move out on to the arete, followed by a couple tricky moves to the anchor.

The big right-facing corner.
Standard rack. Rap rings at the top.

Rather sustained climbing until a hard-to-read crux up top. Classic skaha climbing, with crimps and little ledges for feet. Head right after the third bolt.

Left side of doctors wall. Starts right above the huge flake that's on the ground and moves left to the second bolt, then straight up to the third before moving right to the fourth. Rap down.
10 bolts, anchor. Longer draws could be helpful to reduce rope drag for the first three clips, but not necessary.

A fun and very crimpy line up the right side of the Megawall. Short people will have to do some figuring up top to avoid the huge reach that most will want to do. There are options that keep the grade for those who are vertically challenged.

This route heads up the wall immediately right of the Fixed Draw routes at the Megawall.
7 bolts.

Nurse Minitweak is a shorter version of Dr. Mega tweak, and climbs the Dr. Wall left of Building a Mystery and It is similar in many ways, but harder and the holds are smaller.
Traverse past three permanent chain draws before heading up and slightly right towards a large ear shaped flake And a blank looking head wall.
The climbing gets harder as you near the flake and the crux comes trying to pass it. Several decent rests will help you avoid the pump, but the cryptic, demanding and sequential climbing may thwart an onsight. The anchors are just below a small roof and it is unclear if you should go right to some very small crimps to clip or instead climb left of the anchors to a huge jug where the anchors are harder to reach. The latter seems like a more straightforward ending and it’s a shame that the anchors were not placed a bit closer to the jug.
Really great movement and a worthy project. 

 



Ascends the Dr. Wall just left of the classic .12a “Building a Mystery”. 

Fixed draws and 7 bolts. Chain anchors with fixed lowering biners.

Start in the back of a squeeze chimney for the true OW experience. Grunt your way up the fist crack through several bulging cruxes until it eases off at the top chimney. Alternatively, avoid the crack like the plague and crimp your way through the cruxes (so I've heard!).

The big crack in the middle of the Doctor's Wall.
Only 4-5" gear is going to work for this one! 3-5 BD #4 and 1-2 #5 should suffice. New anchor at the top, to the right. A 60m rope just barely works for rappel. Probably need a 70m for a TR.

An extremely well protected and fun adventure up the steep wall just left of the huge crack that splits the Doctors' Wall on its left. Start below a detached pillar with three bolts that lead to a ledge. You can do this separately, but its fine and easy to just link into Salvation, which starts on top of the pillar.  
  
 Pull onto the wall and clip the very closely spaced bolts from good holds - power through a few small cruxes, clipping more bolts. The sting at the top is the redpoint crux for sure, as the final hold is guarded by either insanely small crimps, or a very powerful lunge, depending on your proclivities.  
  
 A fine route that is well worth doing and projecting, as it is very easy to dog up and project.

The first climb left of the huge crack feature.
14 bolts, anchor. (3 bolts are below the route, 11 on the route proper).

A beautiful, thought provoking, and sustained line up the beautiful featured right side of the Megawall at the Doctors' Wall. Well worth the hike and a must do for anyone touching the grade - positive holds, fun moves, and well bolted, this was probably the best route of my trip.

The left-most route off the Fixed Draws approach. After the last draw, clip the bolt that is down and left, then climb left to the first bolt of the Spell. Back-cleaning all the fixed draws and the first bolt (not in the book) is a good idea and easy to do.
10 bolts and 3 fixed draws.

Fun, athletic climbing up a shallow groove. Near the top, the rock rounds and becomes very polished. The final sequence is on crimps almost impossible to see from below. Good luck!

On the right side of Doctor's Wall. You need to scramble up to the top of the large boulder.
Bolts (10-12, I think)
One of the best areas for hard routes in Skaha; there are many 11s and 12s as well as a few 10s and 13s to round things out.  The harder stuff is consistently steep and spectacular.
